content.title: Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding
content.summary: Bleeding from the GI tract proximal to the ligament of Treitz (esophagus, stomach, duodenum) presenting with hematemesis, melena, or coffee-ground emesis
key_points: Peptic ulcer disease is most common cause (35-50%); varices in cirrhosis patients
Glasgow-Blatchford Score (GBS) identifies patients safe for outpatient management (GBS=0)
Rockall Score predicts rebleeding and mortality after endoscopy
Early EGD within 24 hours for most patients; within 12 hours for high-risk (variceal, unstable)
IV PPI (high-dose bolus + infusion) reduces rebleeding after endoscopic therapy
Variceal bleeding: IV octreotide + antibiotics + endoscopic band ligation
Transfusion threshold: Hgb <7 g/dL (conservative) improves outcomes vs liberal strategy
content.statement: Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) is bleeding from the GI tract proximal to the ligament of Treitz, requiring systematic risk stratification, timely endoscopy, and etiology-specific management to reduce morbidity and mortality.

explanation.intuition: Blood in the upper GI tract either comes up (hematemesis, coffee-grounds) or goes down (melena - digested black tarry stool). The key is stabilizing the patient, identifying high-risk features, and getting to endoscopy for diagnosis and treatment.
explanation.key_insight: Risk stratification is essential: The Glasgow-Blatchford Score identifies very low-risk patients (GBS=0) who can be safely discharged with outpatient endoscopy. Everyone else needs hospitalization and early EGD, with timing based on hemodynamic stability and variceal suspicion.
explanation.technical_details: UGIB pathophysiology varies by etiology: Peptic ulcers bleed from erosion into arteries (left gastric, gastroduodenal); varices from portal hypertension; Mallory-Weiss from mucosal tears during vomiting. Endoscopic hemostasis uses thermal coagulation, clips, or injection for ulcers; band ligation for varices. High-dose IV PPI (80 mg bolus + 8 mg/hr infusion) stabilizes clots by maintaining gastric pH >6.

definitions_glossary.upper_gi_bleeding: Bleeding from GI tract proximal to ligament of Treitz
definitions_glossary.melena: Black, tarry stools from digested blood in upper GI tract
definitions_glossary.ligament_of_treitz: Anatomic landmark at duodenojejunal junction dividing upper from lower GI
definitions_glossary.glasgow_blatchford_score: Pre-endoscopy risk score; GBS=0 identifies safe-to-discharge patients
definitions_glossary.rockall_score: Post-endoscopy score predicting rebleeding and mortality
definitions_glossary.forrest_classification: Endoscopic classification of peptic ulcer bleeding risk
definitions_glossary.stigmata_of_recent_hemorrhage: Endoscopic signs of bleeding: active bleeding, visible vessel, adherent clot
definitions_glossary.variceal_bleeding: UGIB from esophageal or gastric varices due to portal hypertension
definitions_glossary.endoscopic_hemostasis: Techniques to stop bleeding: injection, thermal coagulation, clips, banding
definitions_glossary.proton_pump_inhibitor: Acid suppression medication stabilizing clots by raising gastric pH
definitions_glossary.terlipressin: Vasopressin analog used in variceal bleeding to reduce portal pressure

pathophysiology.mechanism: Mucosal injury, vascular erosion, or variceal rupture causing hemorrhage into GI lumen

variceal: Esophageal varices (most common in portal HTN)

risk_factors: NSAID use (OR 3-4 for peptic ulcer bleeding)

clinical_presentation: Hematochezia (if massive UGIB with rapid transit)
Symptoms of hypovolemia: tachycardia, hypotension, syncope

glasgow_blatchford_score.components: BUN, Hemoglobin, SBP, HR, melena, syncope, hepatic disease, heart failure
glasgow_blatchford_score.interpretation: GBS=0: safe for outpatient management; higher scores = higher risk

rockall_score.components: Age, shock, comorbidities, endoscopic diagnosis, stigmata of bleeding
rockall_score.interpretation: Predicts rebleeding and mortality after endoscopy

laboratory_workup: BMP (BUN elevated suggests UGIB from protein absorption)

resuscitation.fluids: Crystalloid resuscitation; avoid over-resuscitation in varices
resuscitation.transfusion: Restrictive threshold (Hgb <7 g/dL) improves outcomes; transfuse to 7-9 g/dL
resuscitation.reversal: Consider reversal of anticoagulation based on severity and indication

ppi.high_dose: Omeprazole/pantoprazole 80 mg IV bolus + 8 mg/hr infusion for 72h if high-risk stigmata
ppi.oral: Once daily PPI if low-risk stigmata
ppi.mechanism: Maintains gastric pH >6 to stabilize platelet clots

variceal_therapy: Octreotide 50 mcg bolus + 50 mcg/hr infusion (or terlipressin where available)

endoscopic_therapy.timing: Within 24h for most; within 12h if variceal, hemodynamically unstable, or high-risk features
nonvariceal_techniques: Mechanical therapy (clips) - preferred for visible vessel
variceal_techniques: Esophageal varices: Endoscopic band ligation (EBL) preferred
Balloon tamponade (Blakemore tube) as bridge if uncontrolled

rescue_therapy.interventional_radiology: Angiography with embolization for failed endoscopic therapy
rescue_therapy.tips: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt for refractory variceal bleeding
rescue_therapy.surgery: Rarely needed with modern endoscopic and IR techniques

skos.definition: Bleeding from the GI tract proximal to the ligament of Treitz presenting with hematemesis, melena, or hematochezia

subcodes: K25.0 - Acute gastric ulcer with hemorrhage

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features of UGIB (hematemesis, melena, hypovolemia)
Apply Glasgow-Blatchford Score to identify low-risk patients
Determine appropriate timing of endoscopy based on risk features
Describe endoscopic hemostasis techniques for nonvariceal and variceal bleeding
Implement appropriate medical therapy (PPI, octreotide, antibiotics)
Know when to escalate to IR or surgical intervention
clinical_pearls: Glasgow-Blatchford Score of 0 identifies patients safe for outpatient management
Restrictive transfusion (threshold Hgb <7) improves outcomes in UGIB
BUN:Creatinine ratio >30 suggests UGIB (from absorbed protein)
Start PPI before endoscopy - reduces rebleeding if high-risk stigmata found
In suspected varices: octreotide + antibiotics + early EGD + avoid over-transfusion
Forrest Ia/Ib/IIa = high rebleeding risk; needs endoscopic therapy + IV PPI infusion
Nasogastric lavage does NOT improve outcomes and is not recommended
Melena can occur from as little as 50-100 mL of blood in upper GI tract

step1_concepts: Gastric acid secretion and pH regulation
